Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESERARCH: Symbiosis and Repercussions of Extreme Ecological Specificity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The non-photosynthetic plant Pterospora andromedea relies on an obligate relationship with a fungus in the genus Rhizopogon to obtain carbon and energy. This fungus in turn relies on an obligate association with conifer trees to obtain its carbon and energy. Such complex tripartite symbioses have been little studied. However, under conditions of human disturbance or climate change, extreme dependence on highly specific associations within the relationships may lead to population decline. Indeed, populations of Pterospora are in steep decline in eastern North America, but appear to be secure in the west. The proposed research will investigate the historic association, co-migration and genetic structure in Pterospora/Rhizopogon pairs from across North America. The central hypothesis is that health and vigor of this relationship will be highest in the center of its geographic range (e.g. Pacific Northwest) and that populations that exist outside of this optimal center, including those that are disjunct or at range margins (New England), will exhibit lower relative abundance and higher genetic differentiation, possibly due to increased effects of genetic drift and reduced gene flow. This investigation will elucidate historic patterns and variation in ecological specificity in this complex plant-fungal symbiosis and determine factors that explain contemporary patterns of population genetic structure of symbionts at the community level.

This is a collaborative project that involves the synergistic melding of complementary expertise between two research teams, one from a small, liberal arts college (Centre College) and the other at a research intensive University (U of Wyoming). This collaboration will support research training and mentoring of a postdoctoral scholar, and several graduate students. Further, this research will fundamentally enhance the liberal arts learning environment at a primarily rural undergraduate institution by providing a dynamic research opportunity to stimulate the scientific development of undergraduate students and a meaningful mentorship opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit--Over 800 collections of Pterospora andromedea (PTAN) and associated Rhizopogon fungus pairs were made across the United States, Canada and Mexico.  Each pair was sequenced using established chloroplast and fungal barcode primers, and targeted pairs were sequenced with Anonymous Nuclear Loci (ANL) that we developed specifically from Illumina MiSeq sequencing for co-phylogeographic analysis. Microsatellite markers (SSR) were also developed for both PTAN and Rhizopogon from MiSeq data. Two previously unknown Rhizopogon spp. were discovered in association with PTAN, and one taxon was found for the first time to crossover from closely related Sarcodes sanguinea.  Overall, PTAN associates with eight Rhizopogon spp. The data support the presence of four genetic lineages within the R. salebrosus species group, and two within the R. arctostaphyli group, that exhibit strong biogeographic distribution linked to historic conifer association with Pinus contorta and Pinus ponderosa.  Rhizopogon kretzeri, restricted to the eastern disjunct distribution, is most closely related to one of the four R. salebrosus lineages primarily distributed on the eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountains.  The northern Colorado/southern Wyoming border is roughly the location of a hybrid zone between northern and southern R. salebrosus lineages, and a number of hybrid populations were identified. R. arctostaphyli showed the highest degree of specificity with specific PTAN lineages.  PTAN lineages exhibited both high specificity and relaxed specificity for fungal symbionts and autotrophic hosts across the geographic landscape under allopatric and sympatric conditions. This strong evidence for geographic mosaics of specificity in mycoheterotrophic systems is critical in determining the evolutionary ecology of mycoheterotrophs.   

Broader Impacts-- This research involved collaboration between researchers from a Research I University and an Undergraduate Only Liberal Arts College.  One MS (recruited as an undergraduate student) and one PhD were awarded to students involved with research at UW.  Seven undergraduates and REU students (one woman, and 5 first generation college students) were involved in the PTAN project at UW. Sequences of Rhizopogon and PTAN used in our analyses were accessioned into GenBank, along with ANL and SSR primer sequences developed as a part of this research.  Sixteen manuscripts resulted directly from this funding (Dowie et al 2011a,b; Henkel et al 2011; Castellano et al 2012a,b; Miller et al 2012; Kleine and Miller 2013; Grubisha 2014a,b,c; Dowie et al 2016; Thongbai et al 2016a,b; Dowie 2017a,b; Thongbai et al 2017).
